title: Surrendering car in chapter 7 after initially intending to keep
question: I have attended my 341 hearing in which I stated to keep my car through redemption, however the current lender is far away from what I am willing to pay. Is it too late to surrender the car? If not when do I surrender? After discharge? I intend on attempting to "replace" my car through a redemption finance company.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,341 meeting of creditors,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Admissible evidence in criminal cases
answers: The lender doesn't get to decide what the redemption price will be -- a judge does. The standard, according to Code section 506(a)(2), is "the price a retail merchant would charge for property of that kind considering the age and condition of the property" at the time of the redemption hearing. If you've got admissible evidence to back up your valuation, file a redemption motion and present it to the judge. If you lose, you can then amend your Statement of Intention to surrender the car.

Under the 2005 rule changes, if you don't sign a reaffirmation agreement, the creditor can take the car even if you are current on payments. This is not common but it happens every once in a while in my jurisdiction.

I don't say that to scare you, I say that to say, you can give the car back and the rules are such that the Creditor can take it back even if you make payments.

If you decide to keep your car, you should seek the advice of a local attorney who can give you an opinion on the likelihood that you could keep your car without signing a reaffirmation agreement or redeeming the vehicle.

There is nothing wrong with a redemption loan just remember that the fees are high and you need to make sure you can afford the payment because you are stuck with the debt for a considerable period of time because you just filed bankruptcy.

It is not too late to surrender. However, you are obligated under the bankruptcy code to make a good faith effort to transfer the car. That means you need to contact the lender and tell it you are surrendering and then make arrangements.

You can do whatever is best for you. The statement of intention is not binding, nor is your testimony. You are allowed to change your mind. Surrender when you feel like it, if you wait too long, the lender will come and get it, so it is usually a good idea to coordinate the surrender with the lender. You do not want to have your car repossessed while you are paying inside for the gas fill-up you just paid a fortune for!
